Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 2: Collaborative Research: Tenable Power Distribution Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project advances modeling and computational frameworks to guarantee the sustainability of power distribution networks from environmental, economic, and social perspectives. Environmental sustainability is addressed by accounting for the increased uncertainty associated with the rapid and ad-hoc integration of renewable generation and elastic loads. With regard to economic sustainability, computational and inference foundations are put forth to ensure effective and secure market operations in the face of the imminent emergence of large-scale distribution-level electricity markets. Lastly, social sustainability is effected through cyber innovations focused on increasing economic utility and enhancing cyber security.

The proposed research aims for broad socio-technical advances in electricity distribution networks. Successful project completion will offer cyber innovations that enable the systematic integration of stochastic renewable generation while improving end-user satisfaction. Given the ubiquity of the suite of research tools and methodologies, the utility of the proposed research goes well beyond the envisioned application area to the broader fields of optimization, stochastic processes, control systems, machine learning, statistical signal processing, and cyber security. Broader transformative impact will result from pragmatic test cases proposed for validation, involvement of undergraduates in research, and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims at developing computational methods for enhancing the environmental, economic, and social sustainability of next-generation power distribution networks. The proposed research is centered on three thrusts:  coping with uncertainty for environmental sustainability; energy market inference for economic sustainability; and learning from smart meters for social sustainability.  This is a collaborative project with three involved institutions: UMN (lead), UMich, and GWU. The major objective of the GWU participants is to develop computational methods for enhancing the social sustainability of next-generation power distribution networks

Intellectual Merit: The PI at GWU mainly carried out the following research activities: i) developing a privacy-preserving fine-grained smart meter data collection scheme that can support billing at the utility company side based on delayed information release; ii) designing an attribute-based signcryption scheme to secure multicast communications in smart grids; iii) designing an efficient and secure smart meter firmware upgrade protocol based on the proposed signcryption scheme; iv) devising a verifiable access control scheme to secure the ciphertext smart meter data stored in clouds; and v) proposing an affinity propagation based clustering mechanism to help identify vulnerable lines in smart grids for cascading failure prevention. Such research endeavor yields the following results: i) a novel group signature scheme that does not require the signing keys to be updated for each signature calculation; ii) a secret token based scheme that can break the linkage between smart meter readings while allowing the utility company to compute the bills for each billing period; iii) a decryption procedure for the NTRU cryptosystem that overcomes the decryption failures of the original NTRU; iv) a verifiable access control scheme that supports the updates of access policies as well as the smart meter readings in ciphertext stored in clouds; v) a Ciphertext-Policy Attribute Based Signcryption scheme (CP_ABSC) that implements role-based access control while simultaneously providing encryption and signature services; vi) a multicast scheme based on CP_ABSC that can secure the multicast messages to the destinations specified by a set of attributes in smart grids; vii) an attribute and network coding based secure multicast protocol for smart meter firmware updates; and viii) an affinity propagation based clustering mechanism to identify vulnerable lines in smart grid systems for cascading failure and large-scale blackout prevention. One can see that the PI has tackled novel problems and achieved important results toward secure data collection, storage, and communications and enhanced robustness and reliability in smart grids.

Broader Impact: The project at GWU was carried out by the PI who is a female faculty and two PhD students, yielding one PhD thesis and a number of peer-reviewed publications. The PI has been organizing a weekly group seminar open to all graduate students focusing on privacy and security issues in smart grids and other domains and the research findings have been integrated into the courses of wireless and mobile security and privacy-ware computing via course projects and lecture presentations. The proposed schemes can be easily adapted by smart grid service providers to ensure the smart meter data privacy and support billing in smart metering, to support multicasts whose destinations can be defined by a set of attributes, and to identify the set of vulnerable lines in smart grids. The solutions that can ensure practical user privacy can help increase the participation of customers in smart grid applications and enhance the stability of the smart grid system. Moreover, the proposed uses of attribute-based access control, NTRU cryptosystem, group signature scheme, affinition propagation, etc., can help promote more research on similar problems in crowd sensing, cloud computing, Internet of things, and social networking.
